metadata.title: Paakam Puri| పాకం పూరీలు|ఈ పద్ధతి లో పూరీలు చేస్తే కనీసం 15 రోజులు నిలవుంటాయ్|Sweet Puri In Telugu
metadata.description: Learn how to make traditional Andhra special Sweet Puri or Pakam Purilu that stays fresh for at least 15 days. A simple and delicious sweet recipe explained with tips for perfect texture.

transcription_english: [00:00] Hello Foodies, Welcome to Vismai Food. Today's special is Andhra Special Paakam Purilu (Sweet Poori).
[00:05] Is there anyone who doesn't like this? For foodies like me, just the name brings life back.
[00:10] Making it is also very very easy. If made once, they stay fresh for at least 15 days.
[00:15] But it depends on the way you make them. So watch the video carefully till the end. Let's start.
[00:22] First, take one cup, which is a quarter kilo (250g), of Maida (All-purpose flour). You can also use wheat flour here.
[00:27] Add a quarter spoon of salt and one tablespoon of ghee to it, and mix well until it resembles bread crumbs.
[00:34] Then add water little by little and knead it softly for a longer time.
[00:39] The more you knead, the softer and juicier the pooris will turn out.
[00:43] Some people make these pooris like papads. For those, you don't need to knead as much.
[00:47] Cover it with a wet cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
[00:50] Now for the syrup, take double the amount of sugar to maida. So take half a kilo (500g) of sugar.
[00:55] Pour 150 ml of water into it and dissolve.
[00:59] The taste and shelf life of the pooris depend on the consistency of the syrup you make here.
[01:03] If it's a one-string consistency, they stay fresh for four to five days. If you make a thicker syrup, they last for at least 15 days.
[01:09] Swetha has made a one-string consistency syrup here.
[01:11] Once the string consistency is reached, add half a teaspoon of cardamom powder, mix well, and keep aside.
[01:18] Now knead the rested dough well and divide it into small balls.
[01:26] First, roll them out round and thin.
[01:33] Then apply a quarter spoon of ghee on top, fold it to the middle, and fold it again like a cone.
[01:41] Then roll it out slightly thick. Even if rolled thin, they taste good but will turn out crispy.
[01:48] If rolled medium thick, the pooris will be soft and juicy.
[01:56] Now, definitely drop the pooris in hot oil and let them puff up well.
[02:02] If the pan is deep, there is more chance for the pooris to puff up. Remember that if you drop pooris before the oil is hot, they will absorb a lot of oil.
[02:08] Now, as soon as you take them out of the oil, drop them into the hot syrup and leave them for 30 seconds.
[02:14] Only if you drop the pooris while hot, they will absorb the syrup well and become juicy.
[02:18] Otherwise, it will just remain as a coating on top.
[02:21] These pooris have one taste when hot, and another taste when cooled down with the sugar syrup forming crystals on top.
[02:28] Both ways, it tastes very very good. Will you definitely try both ways and tell us how they turned out?
[02:34] For ingredients and tips in this recipe, visit the vismaifood.com website.
[02:38] Don't forget to post the picture of what you made on Vismai Food Instagram.
